definition: Permissible or lawful in Islamic law. For food, it refers to what Muslims are allowed to consume according to Islamic dietary guidelines.
Forbidden or unlawful in Islamic law. Foods that Muslims are prohibited from consuming, such as pork and alcohol.
Meaning 'In the name of Allah.' Muslims say this before eating, cooking, and starting any activity.
The Islamic method of slaughtering animals for meat consumption. The animal must be alive and healthy, and Allah's name must be pronounced during slaughter.
Another term for meat that has been slaughtered according to Islamic law.
Doubtful or questionable. Refers to food items whose halal status is unclear or uncertain.
Disliked or discouraged, but not forbidden. In food context, it refers to items that are better to avoid but not sinful if consumed.
Pure, wholesome, and good. The Quran instructs Muslims to eat what is halal and tayyib, meaning not only permissible but also clean and healthy.
The meal eaten after sunset during Ramadan to break the day's fast. Traditionally begins with dates and water.
The pre-dawn meal consumed before fasting begins during Ramadan.
Blessing or divine grace. In food context, it refers to the blessing in the food that provides spiritual and physical nourishment.
A Middle Eastern spice blend typically containing dried thyme, oregano, marjoram, sumac, and toasted sesame seeds.
A tangy, lemony spice made from dried and ground berries of the sumac bush, commonly used in Middle Eastern cuisine.
A paste made from ground sesame seeds, commonly used in hummus, baba ghanoush, and halva.
Clarified butter that has been simmered to remove water and separate milk solids, which are removed to leave a pure butterfat.
A hot chili pepper paste used in North African and Middle Eastern cooking, made from roasted red peppers, spices, and herbs.
A complex North African spice blend that can contain dozens of spices, including cardamom, clove, cinnamon, and rose petals.
An all-purpose spice blend used in Middle Eastern cooking, typically including black pepper, cumin, cinnamon, and cloves.
An Egyptian condiment consisting of a mixture of herbs, nuts, and spices, typically used as a dip with bread or fresh vegetables.
A soft cheese made from strained yogurt, popular in Middle Eastern cuisine. It has a tangy taste similar to Greek yogurt but with a thicker consistency.
Intention. In Islam, it's important to make a clear intention before acts of worship, including fasting. Saying Bismillah before eating is an expression of niyyah.
Foods that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) regularly consumed and recommended, such as dates, honey, barley, olives, and milk. Eating them is considered virtuous.
A type of date grown in Medina, highly valued in Islamic tradition. The Prophet (ﷺ) said eating seven Ajwa dates in the morning protects against poison and magic.
A natural toothbrush made from the Salvadora persica tree. Often used before eating and during fasting to maintain oral hygiene, as practiced by the Prophet (ﷺ).
Arabic word for bread. A staple in many Middle Eastern and North African meals, often eaten with hands as part of Sunnah etiquette.
Voluntary charity given to help others. Providing food to the poor or guests is a form of sadaqah and brings immense reward in Islam.
Islamic etiquette of eating. Includes saying Bismillah, eating with the right hand, eating from what is directly in front of you, and not wasting food.
Holy water from the Zamzam well in Mecca. It is believed to have healing properties, and the Prophet (ﷺ) encouraged drinking it with specific intentions.
A traditional drink made from dates or raisins soaked in water. It was consumed by the Prophet (ﷺ) when not fermented and remained non-intoxicating.
A tangy fruit used in many Middle Eastern and South Asian dishes. While not directly mentioned in Islamic texts, it's culturally significant in iftar drinks and stews.
